sentences.sentence: The immense momentum shift taking place in Ukraine has seen the Ukrainian military take back areas that have been occupied by Russian forces for months.

With these gains, and reports of massive Russian casualties and loss of equipment, it is increasingly clear that Russia is not capable of achieving victory - so long as liberal democracies continue to supply Ukraine with modern military hardware and intelligence support.As such a humiliation on the world stage threatens the long-term survival of Russian President Vladimir Putin's regime, we are witnessing Russia enter a new phase of desperation.

For the first time since the Second World War, Russia has implemented a massive conscription effort to backfill its battlefield losses.The so-called partial mobilization will call up between 300,000 and one million troops.

However, hundreds of thousands of Russian men have voted with their feet and fled to the nearest border crossing or airport.Putin has also alluded to the potential use of tactical nuclear weapons against Ukraine, and at least one Russian legislator has referenced the possibility of nuclear strikes against European capitals.With all this talk about strategic victories and impending nuclear war, the world must not lose sight of the unfolding human rights horrors in Ukraine, the likes of which Europe has not seen since 1945.Every new Ukrainian counter-offensive reveals evidence of more Russian atrocities.

Civilians shot on their bicycles, mass graves, mutilated bodies, evidence of torture - all have come to light in the liberated areas near Bucha, Kharkiv and Kherson.The United Nations Independent International Commission of Inquiry on Ukraine has documented that children as young as four years old have been raped, and soldiers and civilians have been tortured and unlawfully confined by occupying Russian forces.When the city of Izium was liberated after months of Russian occupation, among the dead in the mass graves were Olesya Stolpakova, 6, her sister Sasha, 8, their mother Elena, 31, and father Dmitry, 33.

Thirty of the 436 bodies in that mass grave showed signs of torture.As described by Oleh Syniehubov, head of the Kharkiv region military administration: "There are bodies with a rope around the neck, with hands tied, with broken limbs and with gunshot wounds.
Several men had their genitals amputated.
"As more territory is liberated, we should expect to find even more evidence of torture, brutality and unspeakable pain.
So what can a middle power like Canada do?
First and foremost, Canada has a moral obligation to continue to supply arms and equipment to Ukraine.
Frankly, in this respect, Canada can be doing more.

Ukraine continues to prove that, if properly equipped, it will defeat Russia.Canada can also take a leadership role in supporting the documentation and prosecution of war crimes, and bringing the perpetrators to justice.

When Andrii Smyrnov, the deputy head of the Office of the President of Ukraine, recently shared an outline for establishing a tribunal to specifically prosecute Russian war crimes, Canada's ambassador to Ukraine urged Ottawa to play a leading role in its launch.The Canadian government is well positioned to take a leadership role through its War Crimes Program, which is delivered jointly by the Department of Justice, the RCMP, the Canada Border Services Agency and Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada.The program's goal is to deny safe haven in Canada to people believed to have committed, or been complicit in, war crimes, crimes against humanity or genocide, and to seek accountability.

But that mandate can be expanded to assist in the investigation and documentation of atrocities in Ukraine, for the purposes of seeking justice through the International Criminal Court.The United States and several European countries have already made moves to help Ukraine pursue justice at the International Criminal Court.

Canada already has a program dealing with these issues, and should use it to bring these war criminals to justice.Bringing war criminals to justice will send a powerful signal to autocrats around the world.

The creation of a special tribunal and the leveraging of existing Canadian government resources won't bring back the victims of Russian atrocities, but it will help save lives in the future.National PostLaryssa Waler Hetmanczuk is a Ukrainian-Canadian Conservative political strategist.

Omar Khan is a Liberal political strategist and media commentator.Adam Zivo: Canada should expel Russian ambassador after he lied about Izyum mass grave(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/adam-zivo-russians-unconscionable-lies-about-izyum)Derek H. Burney: Putin's reckless nuclear threats a danger to us all(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/derek-h-burney-putins-reckless-nuclear-threats-a-danger-to-us-all) !

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
